title: Gradings on $o(8,\mathbb C)$
summary:
This is a matricial description of all the fine group gradings on the
exceptional Lie algebra $o(8,\mathbb C)$. There are fourteen.

summary_detail.value:
This is a matricial description of all the fine group gradings on the
exceptional Lie algebra $o(8,\mathbb C)$. There are fourteen.

author: A. Viruel
fulltext:
arXiv:0709.0194v1 [math-ph] 3 Sep 2007

Gradings on o(8, C)
Cristina Draper ∗
Departamento de Matemática Aplicada, Universidad de Málaga
cdf@uma.es
Antonio Viruel†
Departamento de Álgebra, Geometrı́a y Topologı́a, Universidad de Málaga
viruel@agt.cie.uma.es
November 4, 2018

Abstract
This is a matricial description of all the fine group gradings on the exceptional Lie algebra
o(8, C). There are fourteen.

Keywords: fine grading, maximal abelian diagonalizable subgroup of automorphisms, exceptional
Lie algebra, d4 .

1

Introduction

Given a Lie algebra L, a grading on L is a decomposition of vector spaces L = ⊕i∈I Li such that
Li 6= 0 and for each pair of indices i, j ∈ I there exists k ∈ I such that Li Lj ⊂ Lk (see Definition
2.1 below). Besides of its own mathematical interest, gradings on Lie algebras show up in numerous
applications of physical nature.
As it was already pointed out by Patera et al. in a series of papers on the subject [8, 9, 10, 11, 12],
gradings are in the background of the choice of bases and the additive quantum numbers, and are a
key ingredient when studying contractions that keep "undeformed" certain subalgebra (e.g. see [7]).
Gradings on Lie algebras also play a relevant role in quantum mechanics via Jordan algebras [6]:
given a pair of indices i, j ∈ I verifying (Li Lj )Li ⊂ Li , any element k ∈ Lj gives rise to a Jordan
algebra structure in Li by defining x ◦ y = (xk)y.
Gradings on the algebras o(n, C) have been computed in [1] and [5] for n 6= 8. The case n = 8 is
of special relevance because of its strong symmetry, reflected partly by the triality automorphism.
This makes that our matrices algebra is usually considered as a exceptional Lie algebra. Some works
with a treatment of gradings on exceptional Lie algebras are [2, 3]. Here we describe in detail all
the fourteen fine gradings on o(8, C) (see Section 3). The proof showing that these are all the fine
gradings is lengthy and cannot be included here, so it will appear in [4].

2

Basic concepts

In this minimal section, we introduce the basic concepts we use along this manuscript.
∗ Supported by MCYT grants MTM2004-06580-C02-02 and MTM2004-08115-C04-04, and by JA grants FQM-336
and FQM-1215
† Partially supported by the MCYT grant MTM2007-60016, and by the JA grant FQM-213

1

 Definition 2.1.
A grading on a Lie algebra L over a group G is a decomposition in vector
spaces L = ⊕g∈G Lg such that Lg Lh ⊂ Lgh for all g, h ∈ G (sometimes called group grading). It
will also be required that G is generated by {g ∈ G | Lg 6= 0}. We say that a grading is of type
(h1 , . . . , hs ) when there are hi components of dimension i, and s is the greatest nonzero dimension
of a component.
Definition 2.2.
A grading is called fine when it cannot be refined. A refinement of the
grading L = ⊕g∈G Lg is another (group) grading L = ⊕h∈H Mh such that each component Lg is sum
of several components Mh .
Example 2.1. The main example of a fine grading is the root decomposition in a simple Lie
algebra, which turns out to be a grading over Zl , for l the rank of the algebra.
From now on, L will denote the algebra of skewsymmetric matrices o(8, C) = {x ∈ M at8×8 (C) |
x + xt = 0}. Let eij be the elementary matrix with (i, j)-entry 1, and the remaining entries zero,
and define bij = eji − eij . Then {bij | i, j = 1, . . . 8, i < j} is a basis of L, and the following section
describes the fine gradings on L in terms of this base.
Recall that a grading on L is always the simultaneous diagonalization relative to a commuting
set of semisimple automorphisms (more details in [2]). The grading is fine when it is produced by a
maximal subgroup of semisimple automorphisms, which is usually called a MAD.

3

The fine gradings

We introduce some useful elements of O(8, C) to describe the gradings on L.

Notice that fi , gi , f (a), g(a), h(a), p(a), q(a), r(a), s(a) ∈ O(8, C) = {P ∈ M at8×8 (C) | P P t =
id} for all a ∈ C∗ . Thus we can use the adjoint map to obtain automorphisms of L by means
of Ad : O(8, C) → Aut o(8, C), Ad P (x) = P −1 xP . In particular, denote Fi = Ad fi and Gi =
Ad gi . With all these elements, we are prepared to describe completely the group of automorphisms
producing each grading, denoted by Qi . We also provide the simultaneous diagonalization, which is
a straightforward computation by means of any computer algebra software.

2

Hence it produces a fine grading, of type (25, 0, 1), whose homogeneous components are:

The indices of the components are not the indices of the grading, but the eigenvalues that
{Ad g(2), G1 , G2 , G3 , G4 } act with (e.g. the index { 21 , 1, −1, −1, −1} is for the element (−2, 0̄, 1̄, 1̄, 1̄) ∈
Z × Z42 ). The universal group of the grading (see [2] for the definition) is just Z × Z42 (= χ(Q1 )).
These comments about the universal group and the order and eigenvalues of the automorphisms,
are valid for all the gradings in this paper.
